AC considering plans for Anthropology Dept.
• By RICHARD WARING
A proposal to establish a
Department of Anthropology by
September 1974 is currently
before the Academic Council,
with a decision scheduled to be
made there within the next three
to four weeks.
The proposal, authored by Dr.
Jack Greene, History, and
director of the Atlantic History
and Culture program, would
establish a six -member
department that would cover
social and cultura'
anthroopology. Physical
anthropology and archaeology
would not be included in the
proposed department's area of
study.
The department would be
funded by a five-year Rockefeller
Foundation grant, to be
distributed over eight years, if
the foundation agrees to provide
the financial support. Although
no decision on the grant has yet
been made, Hopkins officials
appear confident that the find

request, for between $800,000
and $1 million, would be
approved Rockefeller early in
1974.
Although some prospective
faculty for the new departmen't
are already at Hopkins in the
Social Relations and History
departments, as many as four
new appointments would have to
be made to staff the
anthropolOgy faculty. One
prospective appointee, Dr.
Richard S. Price, an associate
professor of anthropology at
Yale, was in Baltimore early this
week for talks with University
officials and a tour of the
campus. Only 32, Price
reportedly is attracted to the
opportunity to set up a new
program here.
The new department would
likely offer an undergraduate
anthropology major in its first
year, although the major
requirements are not yet set. "We
should have an undergraduate major
if we have a department," he

added.
If the department is
established, only a small number
of graduate students would be
accepted, and some of them
might come to the department
with faculty members from oh
ther disciplines, such as history
or social relations.
Decision
Greene also pointed out that
even if a decision is made to go
ahead with the anthropology
department, it might not be up

to full strength by next
September. He said, "There's a
question regarding hiring all the
members at once. You have to
build small departments very
carefully."
Once the Rockefeller grant
runs out, the University will have
to provide budgetary support for
the department but Deean of
Arts and Sciences 6eorge Owen
pointed out, "Six man
departments are not a big load on
the budget."

HAC puts off vote on SC conduct code
By ALAN HIRSH
The Homewood Advisory
Council (HAC) postponed
Wednesday afternoon, a vote on
the Student Council's conduct
code proposal and a proposal for
the regulation of dogs on campus
until its next meeting, November
28.
Members of the HAC, a
non-policy making board whose
capacity is strictly an advisory on
to the Vice President for
Homewood Divisions, Dr. George
Benton, who was not present,
agreed that more consideration
by each HAC member of the
S.C.'s proposal was necessary
before full discussion of the
proposal could take place.
Approval of the conduct by
the HAC will, in all likelihood,
mean the adoption of the code
for the University. The Student
Council, after meeting with
Benton and after five weeks
consideration, approved the
nine-sentence, half-page conduct

code October 28.
Before voting on the proposal
for the regulation of dogs on
campus, HAC members agreed
that it would be wise to obtain
some input and feedback from
the Hopkins community on the
proposal.
The proposal for the control
of dogs on . campus reads as
follows: 1) Dogs must be
attended by their owners at all
times, except for 2 below. 2).
Dogs may be left leashed for
short periods of time (10-15
minutes) unattended, but may
not be left leashed for extended
periods of time. Dogs should not
be leashed in places where
barking will disturb academic
activities within buildings
whether attended or unattended.
3) Dogs are not permitted in
campus buildings at any time.
Campus Police will enforce the
above policy in conjunction with
the City Dog Pound.
A number of incidents on

campus where unattended dogs
have chased and threatened
people and have disrupted classes
with barking prompted the
introduction of the dog
- regulation policy several weeks
ago. Comments on the proposal
to the HAC should be sent to
Larry Denton, Office of Vice

Garland Hall.
